Overview¶

The algorithm in this repository optimizes Ogata’s quadrature formula for TMD phenomenology purposes. The work in this repository is based on the Ogata quadrature formula which is given by

\[\begin{align} \int_{0}^{\infty} dx f(x) J_n(x) \approx \pi \sum_{j = 1}^{N} \omega_{n j} f\left(\frac{\pi}{h}\psi(x_{n j})\right) J_n\left(\frac{\pi}{h}\psi(x_{n j})\right) \psi'(x_{n j})\,. \end{align}\]

\(w_{n j}\) and \(x_{n j}\) are the weights and nodes of the quadrature which are defined by

\[\begin{align} w_{n j} = \frac{2}{\pi^2 \xi_{n j}J_{n+1}(\pi\xi_{n j})}\;, \qquad x_{n j} = h \xi_{n j}\; , \qquad J_n(\pi \xi_{n j}) = 0\; \end{align}\]

while the function \(\psi(t) = t \tanh\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\sinh(t)\right)\). The function \(J_n(x)\) is the Bessel function of the first kind and \(n\) is the order of the Bessel function. Here the function \(f(x)\) must be even with respect to the y-axis. \(N\) is the number of nodes used in the quadrature while \(h\) is the node spacing parameter. For further details on this quadrature formula, please see reference [54] in our paper.

For TMD phenomenology, numerical Hankel transforms must be performed from from \(b_\perp\)-space to transverse momentum space, \(q_\perp\)-space. However, integrals of the form

\[\begin{align} W_\nu(q_\perp) = \int_0^{\infty} \frac{db_\perp}{2\pi} b_\perp^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(b_\perp) J_\nu(b_\perp q_\perp). \end{align}\]

tend to be huge bottlenecks of numerical computations.

The algorithm that we present exploits the fact that for TMD applications, the function \(b_\perp^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(b_\perp)\) is a unimodal function. Our integrator takes takes as input \(\widetilde{W}(b_\perp)\), \(q_\perp\), \(N\), as well as \(Q\), a guess for the inverse of the value of \(b_\perp\) at which the function \(b_\perp^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(b_\perp)\) is maximized. From this function and these parameters, the algorithm uses Eq. (21) and Eq.(23) in our paper to find that value of \(h\) which optimizes the performance of the quadrature.
